awd_titl_txt: DDRIE: Economic Consequences of Discrimination Against Minority Bosses by Subordinates
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will use experimental methods to study the causes and consequences of discrimination against minority managers who are underrepresented in leadership positions.  Prejudice, discrimination especially aimed at minority manger, and racial and cultural barriers keep productive people out of, or decrease their effectiveness in, the labor market. Besides human costs, this mis-allocation of talent can slow economic growth, thus preventing countries from achieving their potential to improve the welfare of citizens as well as broaden opportunities for under-represented groups and prevent the development of entrepreneurial talent in low income areas where upward mobility may depend on entrepreneurship.  The focus of this study is on a specific type of discrimination: employees’ discrimination against minority employers and supervisors.  This will be one of the few studies that uses an innovative approach to study discrimination from below.  The findings of this study will be helpful in understanding the extent to which discrimination from subordinate workers thwart the upward mobility of minority groups. It will inform on policies to reduce discrimination in the workplace and provide equal opportunity for all.

This project aims to answer three main questions: (i) Do minority employers and supervisors face discrimination from below in labor markets? (ii) What are the underlying motivations?; and (iii) What are the economic consequences of such discrimination from below? This research will use two field experiments to test for the presence of bottom-up discrimination, and study its economic consequences for minorities in the labor market. This research makes some contributions to the growing empirical literature on the economics of discrimination. This is the first study to provide experimental evidence on discrimination from below in real world field setting. Second, unlike most field experiments on discrimination in labor markets, the experimental design allows for an analysis of the underlying motivations for discrimination from below.  The results of this research has important policy implications to decrease labor market discrimination and improve the efficiency of labor markets and thus increase economic outcomes.  In addition to economic growth, the results of this research project has the potential to provide inputs into policies to decrease inequality as well as expand entrepreneurial and managerial opportunities for under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: Minorities are underrepresented in enterprise ownership and leadership positions in large firms. Why is this the case? This project investigates one possible reason: discrimination against minority employers by their subordinate workers. I conduct a field experiment in the recruitment of entry-level workers by a private firm in India. The experiment aims to answer two main questions: 1) Do minority employers face discrimination in the labor market? 2) What are the underlying motivations for this discrimination? Specifically, I test one possible motive: concerns about social image. There are two main ways that prejudiced workers could discriminate against minority employers. First, they might choose not to work for minority employers, or they may put in less effort once employed. This paper focuses on the first option: it tests whether job applicants are less likely to apply for or accept interview offers from minority employers.

Key Findings: I find that religious minority employers in India receive fewer applications. The quality of those applications is also lower. Applicants randomly assigned to receive interview offers from a minority employer are 10% less likely to attend the interviews. Additionally, the quality of applicants who do attend interviews is lower: they are 9% less likely to have completed 12 years of schooling. I find little evidence that concerns about social image are a primary motivation for discriminating against minority employers.

Main Contributions: This is the first paper to provide experimental evidence of bottom-up discrimination in high-stakes real-world settings. It shows that minority employers face significant disadvantages in the labor market. My project provides complementary evidence alongside other research that has shown that minority-run businesses face discrimination in product markets (Doleac & Stein, 2013; List, 2004) and in accessing credit (Blanchard et al., 2008; Blanchflower et al., 2003). Furthermore, unlike most field experiments on discrimination in labor markets, my design allows me to investigate the motivations behind discrimination from below. The paper demonstrates that discrimination is not simply a case of ethnic sorting among workers, but is specifically targeted at minority employers. This is possible because my research design tracks both the group identity of employers and their potential employees.

Additionally, I test whether discrimination is motivated by concerns for social approval or by a general dislike of minority groups. I find little support for the social image concerns, suggesting that other factors, such as prejudice or biased beliefs, may play a more significant role. The limited research on employee discrimination likely stems from the assumption that employees may not be able to act on their prejudice or that their actions do not have significant economic consequences. This paper challenges that assumption, showing that minority employers are likely to face considerable discrimination, as they attract fewer and lower-quality applicants.

Future Research: While this study demonstrates that minority employers face significant discrimination in entry-level labor markets, further research is needed to better understand the causes and consequences of employee discrimination. Future studies could explore: 1) the level of employee discrimination in mid-level, regular private sector jobs; 2) whether minority employers are aware of the potential penalties they face when hiring labor; and 3) the effectiveness of different strategies that minority employers can use to reduce this form of discrimination.
